question: Please describe in no more than 200 words the following:
gtruth_answer: This in vitro test method is based on human neurons (LUHMES cells) at a stage of neurite growth. It assesses disturbances in (a) the mitochondrial respiration in general, and (b) individual mitochondrial parameters, by exposure to toxicants. The oxygen consumption rate (OCR) and the extracellular acidification rate (ECAR) are measured simultaneously using a Seahorse XF Analyzer. Basal respiration, acute response to test compound, ATP production-coupled respiration, proton leak, maximal respiration, respiratory spare capacity and non-mitochondrial respiration are determined. The data of this method are meant to predict functional impairment of mitochondria. The method has not undergone formal validation and has not been part of a ring trial. It predicts some aspects of neurotoxicity, but not all aspects covered by an in vivo neurotoxicity study (TG424).
gtruth_answer_quality_justification: The answer provides a comprehensive description of the in vitro test method, including the cell type used, the parameters measured, the equipment used, and the purpose of the method. It also mentions the limitations regarding validation and comparison to in vivo studies. This level of detail fully addresses the question within the word limit.
llm_answer: The MitoStressLUHMES assay (MSL) is an in vitro method that uses human dopaminergic LUHMES neurons to assess mitochondrial respiration impairment. LUHMES cells, originally derived from an 8‐week human fetal mesencephalon, are first maintained in proliferation medium and then induced to differentiate into neurons using tetracycline, GDNF, and db‐cAMP. On day 3 of differentiation, the cells are reseeded on coated Agilent Seahorse XFe24-well plates and switched to Seahorse assay medium prior to exposure. During the assay, the oxygen consumption rate (OCR) and extracellular acidification rate (ECAR) are recorded concurrently using a Seahorse XF Analyzer. Specific mitochondrial parameters are derived by sequentially injecting the test compound, oligomycin, FCCP, and a rotenone/antimycin A mix to measure basal respiration, acute response, ATP production, proton leak, maximal respiration, respiratory spare capacity, and non-mitochondrial respiration. The method offers mechanistic information on mitochondrial function as a potential key event in neurotoxicity and developmental neurotoxicity but has not yet undergone formal validation or ring trials. (Source: MitoStressLUHMESassay(MSL).pdf)

Below is a schematic timeline for a typical MSL (MitoStressLUHMES) assay run, showing how the exposure scheme fits into the overall cell culture and assay workflow _(Source: EFSA NAMs Case Study on Tebufenpyrad, Part 2 – Annex A)_:

──────────────────────────────────────────────
Day –1 (Seeding for Proliferation)  
• Proliferating LUHMES cells are seeded in proliferation medium onto standard culture vessels.  
• Cells are maintained in a subconfluent state (generally 40–90% confluency) and cultured on plates pre‐coated with poly‐L-ornithine (PLO) and fibronectin.  

──────────────────────────────────────────────
Day 0 (Initiation of Differentiation)  
• The medium is exchanged from proliferation medium to differentiation medium.  
  – Differentiation medium contains tetracycline (1 µg/ml) which shuts down v-myc, plus GDNF (2 ng/ml) and db-cAMP (1 mM) to drive differentiation.  
• Cells begin to undergo neurite outgrowth.

──────────────────────────────────────────────
Day 2 (Re-plating for the Seahorse Assay)  
• Cells reach ~20–30 million per T75 flask. They are then trypsinized and re-plated into Agilent Seahorse XFe24-well plates.  
• Re-plating is done at a density of 100,000 cells per well in 100 µl of differentiation medium that has been modified—specifically lacking cAMP and GDNF.  
• After ~1 hour of attachment, the volume is topped up to 500 µl per well.  
• Simultaneously, the Seahorse cartridge is rehydrated with XF Calibrant and pre-warmed at 37°C without CO₂.
  
──────────────────────────────────────────────
Day 3 (Assay Day – Exposure and Measurement)  
• Approximately 1 hour before the assay starts, the medium is changed from differentiation medium to Seahorse assay medium.  
  – Seahorse assay medium is based on XF DMEM (pH 7.4) supplemented with 1 mM pyruvate, 18 mM glucose (or galactose for increased sensitivity), 2 mM glutamine, and 2.25 µM tetracycline.  
• At this point, no re-addition of differentiation supplements is performed; the focus is on the assay readout.  
• The assay procedure is initiated:
  – The Seahorse XF Analyzer begins measuring the oxygen consumption rate (OCR) and extracellular acidification rate (ECAR).  
  – Test compounds are injected via the cartridge (first the test compound followed sequentially by tool compounds: oligomycin, FCCP, and rotenone/antimycin A) to determine various mitochondrial parameters.  
  – Further, Hoechst H-33342 is injected with the last injection to stain the nuclei for cell count normalization (imaged post assay using high-content microscopy).  

──────────────────────────────────────────────
Additional Notes  
• The overall assay uses freshly re-plated cells that have already started neurite formation (criteria include approximately neurite lengths similar to the cell body) and a healthy, uniform distribution on the coated Seahorse plates.  
• The coating of plates is critical to avoid aggregation; PLO and fibronectin are applied overnight and the vessels are washed with MilliQ water before use.  
• Critical medium supplements (tetracycline, GDNF, and db-cAMP) appear during the differentiation stage but are deliberately excluded (cAMP and GDNF) in the medium used on day 2 during re-plating to adapt the cells for the Seahorse assay.  
• No test compounds are re-added if a medium change occurs on assay day; compounds are added only via the dedicated injection ports of the Seahorse cartridge.
  
──────────────────────────────────────────────
This graphical timeline integrates the cell culture steps (seeding, medium changes, re-plating on coated plates) with the assay-specific steps (medium change to Seahorse assay medium, sequential compound injections, and final imaging for cell count), thus outlining the exposure scheme in the context of the overall cell culture protocol _(Sources: EFSA NAMs Case Study on Tebufenpyrad, Part 2 – Annex A)_

The MSL assay is designed primarily to assess mitochondrial function by quantifying several specific mitochondrial respiration parameters rather than using cytotoxicity as the primary endpoint. In our protocol the primary endpoints consist of:

 • Acute response to the test compound (i.e. the immediate change in OCR when the test substance is added)  
 • Basal respiration  
 • ATP production-coupled respiration  
 • Proton leak  
 • Maximal respiration  
 • Respiratory spare capacity  
 • Non‐mitochondrial respiration

In addition, a key secondary endpoint is the total cell count per well, which is derived from staining nuclei with Hoechst H‐33342 and subsequent imaging. This measurement serves two roles: it provides a normalization reference for all OCR (and ECAR) values and serves as an indicator of general cellular/cytotoxic effects. In our assay, cytotoxicity is not the primary endpoint but is monitored via the total cell count and the visual evaluation of cell morphology (e.g. healthy nuclear appearance and cell adherence) so that decreases in respiration can be distinguished from non‐specific loss of cells.

Thus, while the focus remains on the measurement of mitochondrial respiratory parameters as the primary readouts, the cell count (and, by extension, cell health parameters) act as reference/normalization endpoints to correct for variations in cell number and to help flag overt cytotoxicity.

(Sources: EFSA NAMs Case Study on Tebufenpyrad, Part 2 – Annex A, sections 5.2 and 5.3)

llm_answer:
The MSL assay is a live-cell metabolic assay that primarily measures mitochondrial respiration using a Seahorse XF Analyzer. In brief, LUHMES cells are differentiated into dopaminergic neurons and then re‑plated in specialized Seahorse plates. On the day of the assay, the cells are maintained alive (i.e. not fixed) in Seahorse assay medium. After an initial baseline measurement of oxygen consumption rate (OCR), a series of injections (test compound, tool compounds such as oligomycin, FCCP, rotenone/antimycin A) are administered sequentially to perturb mitochondrial function and thereby allow calculation of key parameters such as basal respiration, ATP production‑dependent respiration, proton leak, maximal respiration, spare capacity, and non‑mitochondrial respiration _(Source: MitoStressLUHMESassay(MSL).pdf, sections 5.1–5.3)_.

In parallel, at the end of the metabolic measurements, cells are exposed to the nuclear dye Hoechst H‑33342. This staining is performed without prior fixation because the metabolic measurements are obtained in live, intact cells. The stained nuclei are then imaged using a Cellomics Array Scan device where the quantification algorithm identifies nuclei based on predetermined criteria (size, area, shape, and intensity). Roughly 25 image fields per well are captured to yield a robust cell count that is subsequently used to normalize all OCR endpoints _(Source: MitoStressLUHMESassay(MSL).pdf, sections 5.1 and 5.3)_.

Thus, both the metabolic endpoints and the cell count are produced from the same well and under the same conditions. The live-cell approach enables measurement of physiological respiration in real time, while subsequent high‑content imaging provides the necessary normalization via cell counting without the need for additional separate processing steps such as fixation or homogenization.

In summary, the assay’s key steps are:  
1. Differentiation of LUHMES cells and re‑plating onto coated Seahorse plates.  
2. Live measurement of OCR via sequential addition of specific mitochondrial effectors, allowing calculation of several mitochondrial respiration parameters.  
3. Post-assay nuclear staining with Hoechst followed by high‑content imaging to count cells and thus normalize the metabolic data.  

This integrated approach—measuring multiple endpoints (metabolic parameters and cell count) in the same well—ensures that the metabolic readouts are reliably adjusted for potential differences in cell number.

question: Provide information on machine settings, analytical standards, data processing and normalization procedures. For imaging endpoints: provide detailed algorithm. This information should also be covered in an SOP, preferably in DB-ALM format (see link in 6.6).

Below is a summary of the information provided in the documents regarding machine settings, analytical standards, data processing/normalization, and—in the case of imaging endpoints—a detailed description of the image analysis algorithm. Note that much of this information is also contained in the lab‐internal SOP (in DB-ALM format, see section 6.6) that can be requested from the Leist‐lab.

Machine Settings and Analytical Standards  
• For the Seahorse XF Analyzer the following settings and procedures are used:  
 – The instrument is calibrated using XF Calibrant and the cartridge is rehydrated at 37°C without CO₂ immediately prior to the assay (see “4.1 Principles of the culture protocol” and “6.1 Preparation / addition of test compounds”).  
 – Injection port programming is set so that the test compound and tool compounds (e.g. 1 µM oligomycin, 1.5 µM FCCP, 0.5 µM rotenone plus 0.5 µM antimycin A, and 1 µg/ml H-33342) are delivered at precise time points.  
 – The oxygen levels are monitored and must begin at about 150 mmHg and never drop below 60 mmHg during the measurements (“4.3 Acceptance criteria for the test system at the end of compound exposure”).  

• For imaging endpoints, the Cellomics Array Scan VTI HCS high content reader is used with the following machine parameters:  
 – Images are acquired in channel 1 (UV-Hoechst) with exposure times set manually.  
 – Typical image resolution is 512×512 pixels (in 8- or 16-bit format).  
 – The instrument is maintained in routine operation as per the manufacturer’s specifications and stored protocols.

Data Processing and Normalization Procedures  
• Raw metabolic data from the Seahorse XF Analyzer are stored in Wave Assay Result files (.asyr), which include both the metabolic readouts (OCR, ECAR) and metadata (“7.1 Raw data format”).  
• Prior to further analysis the OCR values are normalized to the total cell count per well. The cell counts are captured via the imaging endpoint, as detailed below.  
• Data processing is performed by:  
 – Exporting raw OCR data to Seahorse Analytics and/or Microsoft Excel, where artefacts and outliers (defined by technical issues such as focusing errors) are removed.  
 – Normalized OCR values are calculated using the first overall measurement and the first measurement after each injection for endpoints such as basal respiration, ATP production–coupled respiration, proton leak, and spare capacity (“5.3 Overview of analytical method(s) to assess test endpoint(s)”).  
 – Further statistical treatment (curve fitting, concentration–response analyses) is performed in Excel and GraphPad Prism using a least squares 4-parameter log fit, with quality control including outlier detection based on both biological and technical criteria (“7.4 Curve fitting”).

Detailed Algorithm for Imaging Endpoints  
• Cells are stained with Hoechst H-33342, which is injected with the final tool compound and incubated (25 minutes during OCR measurements and 20 additional minutes post-experiment).  
• The imaging workflow is as follows:  
 1. The Cellomics Array Scan VTI HCS reader acquires images in a predetermined number of fields per well (usually 25 fields) at a resolution of 512×512 pixels.  
 2. Advanced segmentation algorithms within the Array Scan software are used to identify cell nuclei. This algorithm applies predetermined thresholds for:  
  – Object size and area: Only objects within a defined size range are accepted.  
  – Shape criteria: Roundness and other shape features are used to discriminate nuclei from artefacts.  
  – Intensity threshold: Only objects with fluorescence intensities matching Hoechst staining are counted.  
 3. Once nuclei are identified based on these parameters, the total cell count per well is calculated by scaling up the count from the 25 imaged fields based on the well area.  
 4. The resultant cell count is then used as the denominator to normalize the OCR values from the Seahorse analyzer.  
 5. Image quality and focusing issues are documented (for example, if fewer channels or fields are recorded, these data points are flagged and may be excluded).  

All the above data processing and normalization steps—including imaging analysis—are detailed in the lab-internal SOP (provided in DB-ALM format, as referenced in section 6.6). This SOP gives further step-by-step instructions and includes quality control measures and troubleshooting guidelines.

(Sources: EFSA NAMs Case Study on Tebufenpyrad, Part 2 – Annex A)

Highlight the compounds to be used for testing day-to-day test performance, i.e. for setting acceptance criteria (AC). Below is a list (with up to 10 examples) of compounds or manipulations that are used as mechanistic control compounds (MCC) in the LUHMES‐based assays. These MCCs have been selected because they produce biologically plausible changes in mitochondrial respiration or complex activity that match the endpoint readouts. Their well‐characterized effects allow them to serve as day‐to‐day performance controls (i.e. for setting acceptance criteria, AC). The expected responses support that pathway inhibitions or activations are directly reflected in the test method responses. Examples include:

1. Oligomycin  
 • Rationale: Inhibits ATP synthase so that ATP production is blocked.  
 • Expected Data: A significant drop in oxygen consumption rate (OCR) due to inhibition of ATP production–coupled respiration.  
 • Role in AC: Serves as a critical day‐to‐day benchmark showing that the assay is capable of detecting decreased ATP‐linked respiration.  
  _(Source: MitoStressLUHMESassay(MSL).pdf)_

2. FCCP (Carbonyl cyanide-4-(trifluoromethoxy)phenylhydrazone)  
 • Rationale: Acts as an uncoupler, collapsing the proton gradient and allowing maximal electron transport.  
 • Expected Data: An increase in OCR reflecting maximal respiration; this “spare capacity” is used to confirm mitochondrial responsiveness.  
 • Role in AC: Used as a day‐to‐day control to ensure that cells can reach the maximal respiratory capacity when uncoupled.  
  _(Source: MitoStressLUHMESassay(MSL).pdf)_

3. Rotenone (in combination with Antimycin A in the MSL assay)  
 • Rationale: Inhibits mitochondrial complex I (and, with antimycin A, complex III) leading to nearly complete shutdown of mitochondrial respiration.  
 • Expected Data: OCR drops to a very low, non‐mitochondrial respiration level.  
 • Role in AC: Confirms that the assay can detect the low residual respiration baseline and that the “non-mitochondrial respiration” is measured correctly.  
  _(Source: MitoStressLUHMESassay(MSL).pdf)_

4. Antimycin A  
 • Rationale: Inhibits complex III.  
 • Expected Data: When used with rotenone, it ensures the complete block of mitochondrial electron transport and demonstrates the minimum OCR level.  
 • Role in AC: Along with rotenone, used to set baseline (non‐mitochondrial respiration) and to validate the assay’s sensitivity to inhibition.  
  _(Source: MitoStressLUHMESassay(MSL).pdf)_

For the mitochondrial complexes assay (MCL), additional MCCs are used to test individual complex activities:

5. Rotenone  
 • Rationale: Specific inhibitor of complex I.  
 • Expected Data: A marked decrease in cI activity (expressed as a lower normalized OCR compared to control).  
 • Role in AC: Provides a clear positive control for complex I inhibition.  
  _(Source: MitoComplexesLUHMES assay within MitoStressLUHMESassay(MSL).pdf)_

6. Malonate  
 • Rationale: Inhibits complex II by competitively reducing substrate turnover.  
 • Expected Data: A decrease in cII activity (reflected as a reduced OCR after addition of complex-specific substrates).  
 • Role in AC: Acts as a control to verify that the assay can detect selective inhibition at complex II.  
  _(Source: MitoComplexesLUHMES assay within MitoStressLUHMESassay(MSL).pdf)_

7. Antimycin A (again, in the context of complex-specific assessment)  
 • Rationale: Inhibits complex III.  
 • Expected Data: A reduction in cIII activity, as determined by a drop in OCR upon injection in the tier 1 screening.  
 • Role in AC: Confirms proper functioning and inhibition of complex III in the assay.  
  _(Source: MitoComplexesLUHMES assay within MitoStressLUHMESassay(MSL).pdf)_

8. Sodium Azide  
 • Rationale: Inhibits complex IV through binding and inactivation of cytochrome c oxidase.  
 • Expected Data: A reduction of cIV activity observable as a decreased OCR compared to control readings.  
 • Role in AC: Provides a control for testing inhibition downstream of the electron transport chain.  
  _(Source: MitoComplexesLUHMES assay within MitoStressLUHMESassay(MSL).pdf)_

9. Solvent Control (0.1% DMSO)  
 • Rationale: Serves as a negative control ensuring that the vehicle does not affect mitochondrial function.  
 • Expected Data: Minimal change in OCR, serving as baseline for comparing MCC responses.  
 • Role in AC: Validates that observed changes are compound-specific rather than due to the solvent.  
  _(Source: Both assays – MitoStressLUHMES and MitoComplexesLUHMES assay in MitoStressLUHMESassay(MSL).pdf)_

10. (Optional) Digitonin (for permeabilization in the MCL assay)  
 • Rationale: Used in the test method to selectively permeabilize cell membranes enabling access of substrates and inhibitors to mitochondria.  
 • Expected Data: No adverse effect on mitochondrial complex activity when used at the correct concentration; it aids in standardizing the permeability condition.  
 • Role in AC: Included as part of the procedure to ensure consistent test system exposure.  
  _(Source: MitoComplexesLUHMES assay within MitoStressLUHMESassay(MSL).pdf)_

Correlation of Pathway Inhibition/Activation with Test Response  
– In both assay types (MSL and MCL), pathway inhibitions (e.g. by rotenone, malonate, antimycin A, sodium azide) consistently lead to predictable decreases in OCR or complex activity.  
– Activation via FCCP results in an increased OCR.  
Thus, the changes induced by these MCCs (increases or decreases in OCR) correlate directly with the expected response of the test method; they validate that the underlying mitochondrial pathways are being modulated as anticipated.  

The highlighted compounds for setting acceptance criteria (AC) on a day‐to‐day basis are oligomycin, FCCP, and the rotenone/antimycin A combination (for the MSL assay) along with the specific inhibitors (rotenone for cI, malonate for cII, antimycin A for cIII, and sodium azide for cIV) in the MCL assay.

_(Sources: MitoStressLUHMESassay(MSL).pdf, MitoComplexesLUHMES assay details in the same document)_

The rationale for including MG132 is to help identify effects that might not be mediated specifically by mitochondrial complex inhibition but rather reflect unspecific perturbations.  • Prior to an experiment, one stock aliquot is thawed and then diluted in the respective assay medium. For the MSL assay the dilution is made with Seahorse assay medium, while in the MCL assay the MAS buffer freshly supplemented with ADP and digitonin is used.

3. Lab ware, volumes, and dispensing instruments  
 • Dispensing is done using multistepper pipettes to ensure precision.  
 • The volumes in the test are exact: for instance, in the MSL assay, cells are plated initially in 100 µl (then filled to 500 µl after 1 hour) and the compound dilutions (at 10× final concentration) are loaded into the hydrated cartridge ports of the Seahorse XF Analyzer.

 • Temperature: Compound stocks are generally stored at room temperature in DMSO (in a lightproof bottle) as per the manufacturer’s recommendation.  • Lighting: DMSO stocks are kept in lightproof containers to prevent light-induced degradation.  
 • Media for dilution: In the MSL protocol, the Seahorse assay medium is used (composed of Seahorse XF DMEM medium pH 7.4 plus supplemented pyruvate, glucose or galactose, glutamine, and tetracycline); in the MCL protocol, the compounds are diluted in MAS buffer (adjusted just before the experiment with ADP, digitonin, etc.).

 • The final compound dilution is loaded into the cartridge ports of the Seahorse XF Analyzer. This takes place after the medium change to the assay medium on day 3 (for the MSL assay) or after the medium is exchanged for the MAS buffer (in the MCL assay).

In compartmentalized cultures (e.g. in the Seahorse plate), the injection is performed via the dedicated cartridge ports, ensuring that the test compound reaches the cells in the well at the correct timing and volume.

In summary, compound handling follows a sequence that ensures stability (by aliquoting stocks in 100% DMSO and storing in lightproof conditions), precise dilution (to 10× in the respective assay medium, ensuring a final 0.1% DMSO concentration), and automated, precision injection via the Seahorse cartridge system after the medium change on the assay day. question: How are raw data processed to obtain summary data (e.g. EC50, BMC15, ratios, PoD, etc.) in your lab? Describe all processing steps from background correction (e.g. measurement of medium control) to normalization steps (e.g. if you relate treated samples to untreated controls).

OCR and ECAR are calculated directly. These readouts are saved with the meta data (.asyr format) - For further evaluation, the Seahorse metabolic data is uploaded to Seahorse Analytics (https://seahorseanalytics.agilent.com/Account/Login) - Cellomics normalization data is imported and applied - Artefacts and outliers are excluded (see 4.3) - Endpoints are automatically calculated by the pre-set “XF Cell Mito Stress Test” Assay Kit Companion View - Data can then be extracted as Excel files or GraphPad Prism files. Alternatively, generated graphs can be saved as images (png or jpg format)

However, it lacks specific details on background correction, normalization steps, and how summary data like EC50 or PoD are derived. The description is somewhat fragmented and does not fully address the question's request for a comprehensive step-by-step process.
llm_answer:
The extracted raw data from our Seahorse XF Analyzer (OCR, ECAR, etc.) and from our Cellomics imaging readouts (for total cell count via Hoechst‐stained nuclei) are processed as follows (see sections 7.3 and 7.4 of the MSL document):

1. First, the Seahorse XF Analyzer records the oxygen and pH levels and calculates OCR and ECAR. In parallel, images from the Array Scan are used to count cells by detecting nuclei based on size, shape, and intensity. The cell count data are manually transferred (via copy‐paste into Excel) and later merged with the Seahorse dataset.

2. Next, all OCR values are normalized to the total cell count per well. In practice, the first measurement overall and the first readings after each injection are used as baselines. Background correction is performed by subtracting the OCR obtained from medium and inhibitor controls (e.g. the measurement after Rotenone & Antimycin A) so that the subsequent endpoints (such as acute response to compound, basal respiration, ATP production–linked respiration, proton leak, etc.) are derived as differences between these corrected values.

3. The normalized endpoints then serve as the starting point for concentration–response analyses. Data points for each exposure condition are compared to untreated (solvent control, typically 0.1% DMSO) samples. For example, the acute response is calculated as the difference between the post‐injection OCR and the basal OCR, and similar difference calculations are made for other mitochondrial parameters.

4. Finally, the concentration–response data are fitted using a non‐linear (4‐parameter logistic) regression model with least squares in GraphPad Prism. If a non‐linear fit is not achievable, a linear regression is performed. From these fits, summary metrics such as EC50, benchmark concentrations (BMC, where BMC values with upper and lower confidence intervals may be calculated using the online tool “BMCeasy” at http://invitrotox.uni-konstanz.de/BMCeasy/), ratios, and points‐of‐departure (PoD) are determined. Outlier data points (often the result of technical issues like mis‐focus) are identified by visual inspection and excluded.

These steps—from background correction based on medium and inhibitor controls through normalization to untreated control values, and finally fitting dose response curves—form the complete chain from raw data to summary outputs such as EC50, BMC, PoD, etc., as implemented in our lab. 

(Sources: EFSA NAMs Case Study on Tebufenpyrad, Part 2 – Annex A)

The summary data are derived from a procedure that starts with raw OCR or other endpoint values being normalized (to pre-injection or control) and then processed using nonlinear regression. In practice, the data are first processed in Excel and then curve‐fitted with GraphPad Prism using a 4‐parameter logistic (LL.4) model via a least squares approach. question: Provide the statistics of your benchmark response (threshold and variance): (i) For dichotomized data, provide your prediction model. When do you consider the result as toxic or not toxic? (ii) For pseudo-dichotomized outcomes (two classes with borderline class in between): define borderline range. (iii) For multi-class or continuous outcomes: provide definitions and rationale. What is the rationale for your threshold? This can be on a mathematical (e.g. 3-fold standard deviation) or a biological basis (e.g. below 80% viability). Is there a toxicological rationale for the threshold settings and definitions of your prediction model? What are the limitations of your prediction model? What is a ‘hit’ if the test is used in screening mode (= hit definition, if different from above)?
gtruth_answer_quality_justification: No answer provided; treated as missing.
llm_answer:
For the MCL assay (which is used to assess the activity of individual mitochondrial complexes), our prediction model is based on the variability observed in control (baseline) measurements. In our documentation (Section 8.2 of the Annex in the provided context), we define inhibition of a complex as follows:

(i) For dichotomized data the model is formulated so that a complex is considered inhibited (i.e. “toxic”) when its normalized activity is reduced by more than two times the standard deviation (2×SD) of the baseline (control) variation. In the case of complex I, “uncoupling” is similarly defined as an increase in its activity by more than 2×SD relative to baseline. Hence, for a dichotomy:
 • If the change is > 2×SD (either downward for inhibition or upward for cI uncoupling), the response is classified as “toxic.”
 • If the change is within ±2×SD, it is considered non-toxic.

(ii) For pseudo‑dichotomized outcomes – where one might include a borderline class – the “borderline” range is defined as values falling within ±2×SD of the control mean. Responses that fall clearly outside (i.e. < control – 2×SD or > control + 2×SD for cI uncoupling) are classified as toxic, while those within this envelope are viewed as borderline.

(iii) For multi‑class or continuous outcomes the assay endpoints are expressed as percent changes relative to the control value. This permits a grouping (or ranking) of responses. For instance, one could distinguish “no effect” (within ±2×SD), “mild effect” (between 2×SD and a predefined higher fold‐change, for example a threefold change in deviation) and “marked effect” (exceeding that higher threshold). In our application the rationale for using a threshold based on 2×SD is primarily mathematical—to account for inherent assay variability under the same conditions. Alternatively, in assays aimed at measuring cell viability an 80% viability cutoff might be used, reflecting biological rationale, but for our mitochondrial complex activity measurements the statistical baseline is more appropriate. 

Toxicological rationale and limitations:
• The toxicological rationale is that a consistent deviation from the control that exceeds the natural fluctuation (2×SD) is unlikely to be due to random variability. This offers a statistical basis for detecting a true compound‐induced effect.
• However, one limitation is that the threshold is dependent on the quality and consistency of control data. If the baseline variability is high, the 2×SD threshold may be less sensitive. In addition, a statistically significant change does not always directly translate into a biologically adverse outcome.
• In a screening setting (hit definition), a “hit” is defined as a compound that causes at least one of the individual mitochondrial complex activities to change beyond this threshold (i.e. >2×SD deviation compared to control). This hit‐call might be refined in follow‑up testing using more detailed dose–response assessments.

(Sources: EFSA NAMs Case Study on Tebufenpyrad, Part 2 – Annex A, Sections 8.2–8.3)
